article.title: Cursorâ€™s Anysphere nabs $9.9B valuation, soars past $500M ARR
article.content:
Anysphere, the maker of AI coding assistant Cursor, has raised $900 million at a $9.9 billion valuation, Bloomberg reported. The round was led by returning investor Thrive Capital, with participation from Andreessen Horowitz, Accel, and DST Global.
The massive round is Anysphereâ€™s third fundraise in less than a year. The 3-year-old startup secured its previous capital haul of $100 million at a pre-money valuation of $2.5 billion late last year, as TechCrunch was first to report.
AI coding assistants, often referred to as â€œvibe coders,â€ have emerged as one of AIâ€™s most popular applications, with Cursor leading the category. Anysphereâ€™s annualized revenue (ARR) has been doubling approximately every two months, a person familiar with the company told TechCrunch. The company has surpassed $500 million in ARR, sources told Bloomberg, a 60% increase from the $300 million we reported in mid-April.
Cursor offers developers tiered pricing. After a two-week free trial, the company converts users into paying customers, who can opt for either a $20 Pro offering or a $40 monthly business subscription.
Until recently, the majority of the companyâ€™s revenue came from individual user subscriptions, Bloomberg reported. However, Anysphere is now offering enterprise licenses, allowing companies to purchase the application for their teams at a higher price point.
Earlier this year, the company was approached by OpenAI and other potential buyers, but Anysphere turned down those offers. The ChatGPT maker bought Windsurf, another fast-growing AI assistant, reportedly for $3 billion.

article.title: Perplexity received 780 million queries last month, CEO says
article.content:
Perplexity received 780 million queries in May, CEO Aravind Srinivas shared onstage at Bloombergâ€™s Tech Summit on Thursday. Srinivas said that the AI search engine is seeing more than 20% growth month-over-month.
â€œGive it a year, weâ€™ll be doing, like, a billion queries a week if we can sustain this growth rate,â€ Srinivas said. â€œAnd thatâ€™s pretty impressive because the first day in 2022, we did 3,000 queries, just one single day. So from there to doing 30 million queries a day now, itâ€™s been phenomenal growth.â€
Srinivas went on to note that the same growth trajectory is possible, especially with the new Comet browser that itâ€™s working on.
â€œIf people are in the browser, itâ€™s infinite retention,â€ he said. â€œEverything in the search bar, everything on the new tab page, everything youâ€™re doing on the sidecar, any of the pages youâ€™re in, these are all going to be extra queries per active user, as well as seeking new users who just are tired of legacy browsers, like Chrome. I think thatâ€™s going to be the way to grow over the coming year.â€
Srinivas said the reason Perplexity is developing Comet is to shift the role of AI from simply providing answers to actually completing actions on your behalf. He explained that when you get an AI-powered answer, itâ€™s essentially four or five searches in one. On the other hand, AI performing an action would be getting an entire browsing session done with one prompt.
â€œYou really need to actually have a browser and hybridize the compute on the client and the server side in the most seamless way possible,â€ he said. â€œAnd that calls for rethinking the whole browser.â€
He went on to explain that Perplexity isnâ€™t thinking of Comet as â€œyet another browser,â€ but as a â€œcognitive operating system.â€
â€œItâ€™ll be there for you every time, anytime, for work or life, as a system on the side, or like, just going and doing browsing sessions for you,â€ Srinivas said. â€œAnd I think thatâ€™ll fundamentally make us rethink how we even think about the internet. Like, e

article.title: Amazon launches new R&D group focused on agentic AI and robotics
article.content:
Tech giant Amazon plans to launch a new group within its consumer product division that will focus on agentic AI.
Amazon announced this new research and development group at an event on Wednesday, according to reporting from CNBC. This group will be based out of Lab126, Amazonâ€™s hardware R&D division that is behind tech including the Amazon Echo and the Kindle.
The reason this agentic AI group is likely based at a hardware R&D center is that Amazon hopes this group will develop an agentic AI framework to use in the companyâ€™s robotics efforts and to give the companyâ€™s warehouse robots more skills.
TechCrunch reached out to Amazon for more information.

article.title: Anthropic co-founder on cutting access to Windsurf: â€˜It would be odd for us to sell Claude to OpenAIâ€™
article.content:
Anthropic co-founder and Chief Science Officer Jared Kaplan said his company cut Windsurfâ€™s direct access to Anthropicâ€™s Claude AI models largely because of rumors and reports that OpenAI, its largest competitor, is acquiring the AI coding assistant.
â€œWe really are just trying to enable our customers who are going to sustainably be working with us in the future,â€ said Kaplan during an onstage interview Thursday with TechCrunch at TC Sessions: AI 2025.
â€œI think it would be odd for us to be selling Claude to OpenAI,â€ Kaplan said.
The comment comes just a few weeks after Bloomberg reported that OpenAI was acquiring Windsurf for $3 billion. Earlier this week, Windsurf said that Anthropic cut its direct access to Claude 3.5 Sonnet and Claude 3.7 Sonnet, two of the more popular AI models for coding, forcing the startup to find third-party computing providers on relatively short notice. Windsurf said it was disappointed in Anthropicâ€™s decision and that it might cause short-term instability for users trying to access Claude via Windsurf.
Windsurf declined to comment on Kaplanâ€™s remarks, and an OpenAI spokesperson did not immediately respond to TechCrunchâ€™s request. The companies have not confirmed the acquisition rumors.
Part of the reason Anthropic cut Windsurfâ€™s access to Claude, according to Kaplan, is because the company is quite computing-constrained today. Anthropic would like to reserve its computing for what Kaplan characterized as â€œlasting partnerships.â€
However, Kaplan said the company hopes to greatly increase the availability of models it can offer users and developers in the coming months. He added that Anthropic has just started to unlock capacity on a new computing cluster from its partner, Amazon, which he says is â€œreally big and continues to scale.â€
As Anthropic pulls away from Windsurf, Kaplan said heâ€™s collaborating with other customers building AI coding tools, such as Cursor â€” a company Kaplan said Anthropic expects to work with for a long time. Kaplan

article.title: Google says its updated Gemini 2.5 Pro AI model is better at coding
article.content:
Google on Thursday announced an update to its Gemini 2.5 Pro preview model that the company claims is better at certain programming tasks.
The companyâ€™s calling it an â€œupdated preview,â€ building on the upgrade to Gemini 2.5 Pro that Google announced around a month ago. Google says the model will roll out in general availability in a â€œcouple of weeksâ€ and is available starting today in its AI developer platforms AI Studio and Vertex AI and the Gemini app.
â€œ[Gemini 2.5 Pro] continues to excel at coding, leading on difficult coding benchmarks,â€ Google wrote in a blog post. â€œIt also shows top-tier performance [on]Â highly challenging benchmarks that evaluate a modelâ€™s math, science, knowledge, and reasoning capabilities.â€
So what else is new? Google says it addressed feedback from its previous 2.5 Pro release, improving the modelâ€™s style and structure. Now 2.5 Pro can be â€œmore creative with better-formatted responses,â€ Google claims.

article.title: Anthropic unveils custom AI models for US national security customers
article.content:
Anthropic says it has released a new set of AI models tailored for U.S. national security customers.
The new models, a custom set of â€œClaude Govâ€ models, were â€œbuilt based on direct feedback from our government customers to address real-world operational needs,â€ writes Anthropic in the blog post. Compared to Anthropicâ€™s consumer- and enterprise-focused models, the new custom Claude Gov models were designed to be applied to government operations like strategic planning, operational support, and intelligence analysis.
â€œ[These] models are already deployed by agencies at the highest level of U.S. national security, and access to these models is limited to those who operate in such classified environments,â€ writes Anthropic in its post. â€œ[They] underwent the same rigorous safety testing as all of our Claude models.â€
Anthropic has increasingly engaged U.S. government customers as it looks for dependable new sources of revenue. In November, the company teamed up with Palantir and AWS, the cloud computing division of Anthropicâ€™s major partner and investor, Amazon, to sell Anthropicâ€™s AI to defense customers.
Anthropic says its new custom Claude Gov models better handle classified material, â€œrefuse lessâ€ when engaging with classified information, and have a greater understanding of documents within intelligence and defense contexts. The models also have â€œenhanced proficiencyâ€ in languages and dialects critical to national security operations, Anthropic says, as well as â€œimproved understanding and interpretation of complex cybersecurity data for intelligence analysis.â€
Anthropic isnâ€™t the only top AI lab going after defense contracts.
OpenAI isÂ seekingÂ to establish a closer relationship with the U.S. Defense Department, and Meta recently revealedÂ that itâ€™s making itsÂ LlamaÂ models available to defense partners. Google is refining a version of its Gemini AI capable of working within classified environments. Meanwhile, Cohere, which primarily builds AI products for businesses, i

article.title: The founder of DeviantArt is making a $22,000 display for digital art
article.content:
Angelo Sotira started the online digital art platform DeviantArt when he was just a teenager, growing a formative community for millions of artists in the 2000s. Twenty-five years later, Sotira wants to change digital art again, but with a focus on the way itâ€™s displayed.
On Thursday, Sotira revealed his new venture, Layer, a screen specifically designed to showcase digital art in the best quality possible.
â€œThe way that the canvas needs to perform and behave in your life is quite different than other types of displays,â€ Sotira told TechCrunch. â€œIt needs to blend into beautiful environments.â€
The closest point of reference that the average consumer would have for a product like this is Samsungâ€™s The Frame TV, which looks like a painting hung on the wall when itâ€™s not turned on. But Layer takes that kind of feel to an even more premium level â€” unlike The Frame, Layer is not a consumer product, and itâ€™s not trying to emulate static paintings or photographs.
â€œTheyâ€™re $22,000, so that kind of tells you a lot about who thatâ€™s for,â€ Sotira said. â€œWe spared no expense and we spared no effort. We made no compromise in producing what is actually, in our opinion, the very best way to display digital art on a wall.â€
When Sotira talks about digital art, he isnâ€™t talking about digital photography or videos.
Layer is working with hundreds of artists like Casey Reas, who makes generative art â€” no, not the kind of generative AI art like youâ€™d get from ChatGPT, which is created with LLMs that use other artistsâ€™ work without their consent. Instead, many of these artists are writing their own software to create digital artworks that change over time according to what the code says.
But these artworks can require a lot of computing power to execute. Thatâ€™s part of why Layer is so pricey â€” it needs the technological capacity to display these new kinds of works.
â€œYouâ€™re looking at an over 35-year history of extraordinary artists developing the medium of code-based art and essentially, th
